MOSQITO
  • mosqito.sq_metrics
  • mosqito.sq_metrics.loudness.loudness_zwtv
  • <no title>
  • View page source
loudness_zwtv(signal, fs, field_type='free')[source]ÔÉÅ

Returns the loudness value

This function computes the acoustic loudness according to Zwicker method for time-varying signals.

Parameters:

  • signal (array_like or DataTime object) ‚Äì Signal time values [Pa], dim (nperseg, nseg).

  • fs (float, optional) ‚Äì Sampling frequency, can be omitted if the input is a DataTime object. Default to None

  • field_type ({'free', 'diffuse'}) ‚Äì Type of soundfield corresponding to spec_third. Default is ‚Äòfree‚Äô

Returns:

  • N (float) ‚Äì Overall loudness [sones], size (Ntime,).

  • N_specific (numpy.ndarray) ‚Äì Specific loudness [sones/bark], size (Nbark, Ntime).

  • bark_axis (numpy.ndarray) ‚Äì Bark axis, size (Nbark,).

  • time_axis (numpy.ndarray) ‚Äì Time axis, size (Ntime,).

See also

loudness_zwst

loudness computation for a stationary time signal

loudness_zwst_perseg

loudness computation by time-segment

loudness_zwst_freq

loudness computation from a sound spectrum

Notes

Normative reference:

ISO 532:1975 (method B) DIN 45631:1991 ISO 532-1:2017 (method 1)

Due to normative continuity, as defined in the preceeding standards, the method is in accordance with ISO 226:1987 equal loudness contours (instead of ISO 226:2003).

References

[ZF]

E.Zwicker and H.Fastl, ‚ÄúProgram for calculating loudness according to DIN 45631 (ISO 532B)‚Äù, J.A.S.J (E) 12, 1 (1991).

Examples

>>> from mosqito.sq_metrics import loudness_zwtv
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> import numpy as np
>>> fs=48000
>>> d=1
>>> dB=60
>>> time = np.arange(0, d, 1/fs)
>>> f = np.linspace(1000,5000, len(time))
>>> stimulus = 0.5 * (1 + np.sin(2 * np.pi * f * time))
>>> rms = np.sqrt(np.mean(np.power(stimulus, 2)))
>>> ampl = 0.00002 * np.power(10, dB / 20) / rms
>>> stimulus = stimulus * ampl
>>> N, N_spec, bark_axis, time_axis = loudness_zwtv(stimulus, fs)
>>> plt.plot(time_axis, N)
>>> plt.xlabel("Time [s]")
>>> plt.ylabel("Loudness [Sone]")

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)
